Graphical abstract Benefiting from the crystal field alteration and electron redistribution on the active Fe sites, the ORR and Zn-air battery performance of Fe-N-C catalysts can be signifiantly enhanced by introducing moderate ultra-small Fe2O3 nanoclusters. Metal-air batteries face a great challenge in developing efficient and durable low-cost oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) electrocatalysts. Single-atom iron catalysts embedded into nitrogen doped carbon (Fe-N-C) have emerged as attractive materials for potential replacement of Pt in ORR, but their catalytic performance was limited by the symmetrical electronic structure distribution around the single-atom Fe site. Here, we report our findings in significantly enhancing the ORR performance of Fe-N-C by moderate Fe2O3 integration via the strong electronic interaction. Remarkably, the optimized catalyst (M−Fe2O3/FeSA@NC) exhibits excellent activity, durability and good tolerance to methanol, outperforming the benchmark Pt/C catalyst. When M−Fe2O3/FeSA@NC catalyst was used in a practical zinc-air battery assembly, peak power density of 155 mW cm−2 and specific capacity of 762 mA h gZn −1 were achieved and the battery assembly has shown superior cycling stability over a period of 200 h. More importantly, theoretical studies suggest that the introduction of Fe2O3 can evoke the crystal field alteration and electron redistribution on single Fe atoms, which can break the symmetric charge distribution of Fe-N4 and thereby optimize the corresponding adsorption energy of intermediates to promote the O2 reduction. This study provides a new pathway to promote the catalytic performance of single-atom catalysts. Keywords Single-atom catalysts Oxide nanoclusters Electronic interactions Oxygen reduction reaction Zn-air battery 1 Introduction The increasing consumption of traditional fossil fuels and increasingly serious environmental pollution have greatly promoted the development of efficient, clean and renewable energy-based devices (e.g., fuel cells, water splitting, and batteries) [1–3]. Among these technologies, rechargeable zinc-air batteries (ZABs) are showing great potential for emerging electronic applications due to the unique advantages of operational safety, environmental-friendliness and a high theoretical energy density of 1370 Wh kg−1. Such energy advantage is attributed to their unique “half-open” cell structure, in which atmospheric oxygen can be electrocatalytically reduced and evolved at the cathode. However, their industrial implementation is severely impeded by the poor cycling life and sluggish kinetics of cathodic ORR [4–10]. Currently, platinum (Pt)-based materials (especially commercial Pt/C) are typically taken as the benchmark ORR electrocatalyst, but they suffer from prohibitive cost, rare reserves and poor durability. Thus, tremendous attention has been drawn to design efficient non-precious-metal-based catalysts (NPMCs) for ORR [3,11–13]. Among various NPMCs, nitrogen coordinated iron single atoms on carbon matrix (Fe-N-C) are regarded as one of the most potential catalysts to substitute for Pt by virtue of their low cost and efficient ORR activity [14–16]. It is commonly recognized that the four-nitrogen coordinated atomic Fe sites (i.e., Fe-N4 moieties) within the carbon framework dominate the ORR activity in Fe-N-C. Based on the Sabatier principle, the ORR active center needs to bind with oxygen intermediate with moderate strength, i.e., the interaction between the catalyst active site and the surface adsorbed oxygen species should be neither too strong nor too weak [4,17–20]. However, previous studies reported that the symmetric electronic structure distribution of the typical Fe-N4 configuration is not conducive to the optimal oxygen intermediate adsorption, leading to limited catalytic performance [4,21,22]. Hence, it is desirable to better tune the ORR activity of Fe-N-C by rationally adjusting the electronic structure of Fe-N4 site. To date, two common approaches have been developed to enhance the intrinsic activity of atomic Fe centers by modulating their electronic structures. One is introducing adjacent metal centers (e.g., Pt, Cu and Co) into Fe-N-C to trigger the electronic structure redistribution [8,23–25]. For example, the activity of the Fe-N4 can be increased by introducing adjacent Pt-N4, which could modulate the 3d orbitals of the Fe-N4 active site [23]. Bimetal sites (Fe-Cu) rather than single metal active sites (Fe) lead to promoted oxygen dissociation and thus show enhanced ORR activity [24]. Another strategy is to partially replace N atoms in Fe-N4 with different heteroatoms (e.g., S, P and B) to generate an asymmetrically coordinated Fe active site. Doping heteroatoms can alter the electronic structure of the Fe-N4 active center [4,22,26]. Furthermore, a few recent studies have also indicated that the introduction of some exterior groups (such as metallic nanoparticles/nanoclusters and metal carbides) near Fe-N4 can accelerate the ORR, which motivates the research on systems containing atomic active sites and the second phase [4,11,22,27,28]. For instance, in Gao’s study, the adjacent Fe clusters can significantly promote the intrinsic activity of Fe-Nx moieties by adjusting their electronic structure [27]. In another case, Cui et al. reported that the interaction between atomic Fe-N x sites and Fe3C nanoparticles favors the adsorption of O2 molecule, thus boosting the ORR performance [11]. Nevertheless, the analysis of the underlying cause of the introduced exterior groups for enhancing the activity is still not thoroughly enough. Besides, the influence of the content of introduced exterior groups on the ORR activity of Fe-N-C is still unclear and requires further in-depth study. In this study, we prepared a highly efficient ORR catalyst comprising single-atom Fe sites integrated with ultra-small Fe2O3 nanoclusters/nanoparticles embedded within N-doped porous carbons (denoted as Fe2O3/FeSA@NC) by using a cage-encapsulated-precursor pyrolysis strategy. Fe2O3 contents in Fe2O3/FeSA@NC are tunable by changing the molar ratios of Fe/Zn in the imidazolate precursors in a range from low value of Fe/Zn = 1:30 (denoted as L-Fe2O3/FeSA@NC), moderate value of Fe/Zn = 1:20 (denoted as M−Fe2O3/FeSA@NC) to high value of Fe/Zn = 1:10 (denoted as H-Fe2O3/FeSA@NC). Highest ORR activity was observed for the M−Fe2O3/FeSA@NC catalyst with moderate Fe2O3 content, displaying an onset potential of 1.05 V, a half-wave potential of 0.84 V and a kinetic current density of 14.62 mA cm−2@0.80 V, which outperforms the Pt/C under the same testing circumstance. On top of high activity, it also shows excellent methanol tolerance and operation durability. Theoretical calculations demonstrate that the introduction of Fe2O3 can increase the valence state and change the crystal field (from square-planar to tetrahedral) of the active single-atom Fe sites, thus optimizing HO* adsorption to improve ORR activity. Moreover, a ZAB with a catalyst (M−Fe2O3/FeSA@NC and RuO2) exhibits a high peak power density of 155 mW cm−2, a specific capacity of 762 mA h gZn −1, and robust stability over a period of 200 h, demonstrating great promise for industrial applications as energy storage and conversion devices. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Zinc nitrate hexahydrate (Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, ≥99.0% (KT)), hemin (C34H32ClFeN4O4, ≥96.0% (HPLC)), 2-methylimidazole (C4H6N2, 99%), ruthenium(IV) oxide (RuO2), zinc acetate (Zn(OAc)2), potassium hydroxide (KOH) and Nafion solution (5 wt%) were directly acquired from the company of Sigma-Aldrich. The commercial Pt/C catalyst was purchased from the company of Johnson Matthey. Methanol (CH3OH) and ethanol (C2H5OH) were received from Ajax Finechem. All reagents were used as obtained and required no further purification. 2.2 Sample preparation 2.2.1 Synthesis of L-Fe-Hemin@ZIF-8, M−Fe−Hemin@ZIF-8, H-Fe-Hemin@ZIF-8 and ZIF-8 In a typical procedure, two solutions were prepared. Solution A: 0.84 g Zn(NO3)2·6H2O and 0.091 g hemin (Fe/Zn molar ratio: 1:20) were added in 40 mL of methanol; Solution B: 1.85 g of 2-methylimidazole was added in 40 mL of methanol. Solution A was then mixed with solution B and kept stirred for 24 hours at room temperature. The as-prepared precipitate was collected by the centrifugation and rinsed several times with methanol and finally left to dry at 65 °C overnight prior to use (denoted as M−Fe−Hemin@ZIF-8). The experimental procedures for the preparation of L-Fe-Hemin@ZIF-8 and H-Fe-Hemin@ZIF-8 were almost similar to that of M−Fe−Hemin@ZIF-8, except for changing the amount of hemin (0.061 g for L-Fe-Hemin@ZIF-8 (Fe/Zn molar ratio: 1:30) and 0.182 g for H-Fe-Hemin@ZIF-8 (Fe/Zn molar ratio: 1:10)). ZIF-8 was also synthesized without adding hemin. 2.2.2 Synthesis of L-Fe2O3/FeSA@NC, M−Fe2O3/FeSA@NC, H-Fe2O3/FeSA@NC and NC The obtained powders of L-Fe-Hemin@ZIF-8, M−Fe−Hemin@ZIF-8, H-Fe-Hemin@ZIF-8 and ZIF-8 were heated in a tube furnace. The powders were heated from room temperature to 900 °C at the rate of 5 °C min−1 under constant Ar flow. After cooling to room temperature, the resulting products were named L-Fe2O3/FeSA@NC, M−Fe2O3/FeSA@NC, H-Fe2O3/FeSA@NC and NC and used without further treatment. 2.3 Sample characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were conducted using a Rigaku Miniflex 600 X-ray diffractometer with Cu-Kɑ radiation within the 2θ range of 5°–85°. The sample morphology was characterized by using a FEI Quanta 3D FIB-SEM and a FEI Tecnai G2 T20 TEM. Atomic resolution high-angle annular dark field-scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) images were taken on a FEI Titan3 80–300 FEGTEM at 300 kV. N2-sorption experiment was carried out using Micromeritics 3Flex instrument. Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method was adopted to calculate the surface area while the corresponding pore size distributions were estimated according to the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. Inductively coupled plasma-mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) was taken in a Thermo iCAP TQe Triple Quadrupole ICP-MS. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was taken on a Nexsa Surface Analysis System. X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) for the Fe K-edge was collected at the BL 44A beamline of the National Synchrotron Radiation Research Center in Taiwan, China. 2.4 Electrochemical measurements All ORR tests were conducted on the CHI760E equipped with a three-electrode cell, i.e., working electrode: a glassy carbon electrode deposited with the catalyst ink; reference electrode: a Ag/AgCl electrode; counter electrode: a platinum foil. The catalyst ink was prepared as follows: 240 μL of deionized (DI) water, 720 μL of ethanol, 40 μL of Nafion solution (5 wt%) and 5 mg of catalyst were mixed. The mixture was then placed in ultrasonication for ∼1 h. 10 μL of this homogeneous ink was dropwisely added onto the electrode surface and left to dry in natural condition. Final mass loading of the catalyst is ∼0.255 mg cm−2. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) tests were taken in the O2 or N2-saturated 0.1 M KOH with the scan rate = 100 mV s−1. To evaluate the ORR activity, linear scanning voltammetry (LSV) profiles were performed in O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH with the scan rate = 5 mV s−1 , and the rotating speed of the rotating disk electrode (RDE) was varied from 400 to 2500 r min−1. With CV measurements ranging from 2 to 12 mV s−1, the electrochemical surface area (ECSA) was determined by the double-layer capacitance (C dl). For the ORR at an RDE, the electron transfer number (n) and kinetic current density (J k) were calculated according to the Koutecky-Levich equation. The stability tests of the catalysts were taken in the O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH with potential cycling from 0.4 to 1.0 V (vs. RHE) for 1000 cycles. 2.5 Zinc-air battery Zinc-air batteries (ZABs) were assembled with a homemade mold. The air cathode with a catalyst was prepared by a drop-casting method where the slurry with 5 mg catalyst (e.g., 2.5 mg M−Fe2O3/FeSA@NC and 2.5 mg RuO2), 720 μL of C2H5OH, 240 μL of DI H2O, and 40 μL of Nafion solution (5 wt%) was coated on a commercially available carbon fiber film (AvCarb P75T). The areal loading on the air cathode is 1 mg cm−2. The anode is a metallic Zn plate. 6 M KOH and 0.2 M zinc acetate (Zn(Ac)2) in the aqueous solution were used as the electrolyte. The ZABs were evaluated at room temperature and in an air atmosphere. Open discharge polarization and power density curves were evaluated on the BioLogic VSP Potentiostat. Galvanostatic discharge and galvanostatic cycling curves were evaluated on the LANHE battery tester. 2.6 Computational methods All density functional theory (DFT) computations with the projector augmented wave (PAW) method were performed by using the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) based on [29,30]. The spin-polarization was considered in all calculations. Standard PAW potentials were employed to describe Electron-ion interactions, with valence configurations of 3s 23p 64s 23d 6/ L for Fe (Fe_sv), 2s 22p 2 for C (C), 2s 22p 3 for N (N), 2s 22p 4 for O (O), and 1 s 1 for H (H). A plane-wave basis set was adopted to expand the smooth part of the wave functions with a cut-off kinetic energy of 520 eV. A form of the general gradient approximation (GGA) (i.e., the functional parameterized by Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) [31]), was adopted for the electron–electron exchange and correlation interactions. As traditional DFT calculations could not accurately describe the nonlocal van der Waals interactions at the PBE level, DFT‐D3 method was adopted to account for dispersion corrections in this work [32,33]. In view of the magnitude of Coulombic repulsion between the localized d electrons of TMs, the DFT + U method was chosen to correct the TM oxides [34]. The U-J value of Fe was determined to be 4.3 according to our previous studies [35–37]. 3 Results and discussion The preparation procedure of the Fe2O3/FeSA@NC catalysts is illustrated in Fig. 1 . Fe-Hemin complexes are encapsulated in the molecular-scale cages of zeolite imidazolate frameworks (ZIF-8). The obtained samples are expressed as Fe-Hemin@ZIF-8. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of Fe-Hemin@ZIF-8 show the same diffraction peaks as pure ZIF-8 (Fig. S1), indicating good crystallinity and a similar zeolite-type structure. The scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images reveal that the Fe-Hemin@ZIF-8 precursors have a regular rhombododecahedron morphology, while a lower Fe/Zn ratio provides a smaller particle size (Fig. S2). For example, Fe/Zn ratios of 1:30 and 1:20 result in Fe-Hemin@ZIF-8 particles with sizes of ∼100–200 nm, which are smaller than Fe/Zn ratios of 1:10 with an average particle size around 700–800 nm (Table S1). Upon pyrolysis at 900 °C, Zn readily evaporated, generating uniformly dispersed Fe single-atoms and Fe2O3 clusters/nanoparticles anchored on porous N-doped carbon (Fe2O3/FeSA@NC). The formation of Fe2O3 can be attributed to the combination of Fe species and the oxygen generated from the O-containing functional groups at the surface of the precursor during high-temperature pyrolysis [38–40]. Without adding the Fe source, N-doped carbon (denoted as NC) was also obtained for comparison. As seen from Fig. S3, no peaks assigned to metallic Fe or Fe oxides were reflected in the XRD patterns. Further morphological characterization, including SEM (Fig. 2 a–c and Fig. S4) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) (Fig. 2d and Fig. S5), shows that all the pyrolyzed samples retain their initial dodecahedral shape but exhibit smaller particle sizes and relatively rough surfaces. Texture properties of Fe2O3/FeSA@NC sample were examined by N2-sorption isotherms. Fig. S6(a) displays a type-I isotherm, indicating the existence of micropores in Fe2O3/FeSA@NC. In addition, the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area of Fe2O3/FeSA@NC increases with the decreasing Fe content (Table S2). Specifically, the BET surface areas of L-Fe2O3/FeSA@NC and M−Fe2O3/FeSA@NC were calculated to be 748.6 and 708.0 m2 g−1, respectively, higher than that of H-Fe2O3/FeSA@NC (483.3 m2 g−1). On the basis of pore size distribution (Fig. S6b and Table S2), L-Fe2O3/FeSA@NC and M−Fe2O3/FeSA@NC have much larger pore volumes than H-Fe2O3/FeSA@NC, revealing that the sample with a relatively low Fe content is preferred for introducing micropores. Both high surface area and rich pores in M−Fe2O3/FeSA@NC help increase the active sites and facilitate the mass transport during the ORR [41,42]. The carbon structure in Fe2O3/FeSA@NC was further characterized by Raman spectroscopy. Two distinct bands situated at ∼1355 and 1588 cm−1 correspond to the defective carbon (D band) and the graphitic carbon (G band), respectively (Fig. S7) [43,44]. M−Fe2O3/FeSA@NC sample possesses the highest I D/I G ratio, suggesting that the moderate Fe content in Fe2O3/FeSA@NC is capable to facilitate the creation of carbon defects, which are conducive to anchoring the single Fe atoms and boosting ORR activity [3,5,45,46]. Moreover, the distribution of Fe species at atomic level was revealed by high-angle annular dark-field scanning TEM (HAADF-STEM). In L-Fe2O3/FeSA@NC, the isolated bright dots correspond to single Fe atoms embedded in the carbon matrix (Fig. 2e). In contrast, in addition to single Fe atoms (marked with yellow dashed circles), Fe2O3 nanoclusters with sizes of ∼2–3 nm and nanoparticles with sizes of ∼3–10 nm (marked with blue dashed circles) were also clearly observed in the M−Fe2O3/FeSA@NC and H-Fe2O3/FeSA@NC derived from higher Fe/Zn ratios (Fig. 2f and g). To validate the co-existence of Fe2O3 nanoclusters/nanoparticles and Fe single atoms, more HAADF-STEM images were taken for M−Fe2O3/FeSA@NC and H-Fe2O3/FeSA@NC in different regions (Figs. S8 and S9). Energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) mappings (Fig. 2h and Figs. S10 and S11) were used to understand the distribution of different elements. Notably, the elemental distribution density of Fe species increases with increasing Fe content in Fe2O3/FeSA@NC, which is in accordance with the results quantified by inductively coupled plasma-mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) analysis (Table S3). Above analysis demonstrate that Fe single atoms together with various Fe2O3 nanoclusters/nanoparticles were successfully anchored on N-doped porous carbon. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was employed to analyze the chemical states of surface species. XPS spectra in Fig. 3 (a) confirm the existence of C, N and O in tested samples. After introducing Fe, one weak peak emerges at ∼711 eV for H-Fe2O3/FeSA@NC, which may be due to low surface Fe ratio. Fe 2p XPS spectra of Fe2O3/FeSA@NC show two prominent peaks at 711.1 and 724.7 eV (Fig. 3b), which are higher than those of Fe metal (707.4 and 719.7 eV), implying that the Fe species in Fe2O3/FeSA@NC exist in a positively oxidized state rather than metallic zero-valent Fe [47,48]. N 1s of XPS spectra (Fig. 3c and Table S4) could be deconvoluted into four individual peaks, namely, 398.3 eV for pyridinic N, 399.2 eV for pyrrolic N, 400.8 eV for graphitic N and 403.3 eV for oxidized N [2,49]. The dominant N species in M−Fe2O3/FeSA@NC are pyridinic N and graphitic N, which both can boost ORR catalysis [48,50,51]. To further examine the local electronic and coordination configuration of Fe2O3/FeSA@NC, this sample was subjected to X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) measurements, including both X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS). Fig. 3(d) displays the XANES spectra of Fe2O3/FeSA@NC, and reference materials of Fe foil, Fe3O4 and Fe2O3 are also included for comparison. One small pre-edge peak of Fe2O3/FeSA@NC is located at ∼7114 eV, which deviates from the Fe-N4 square-planar (7118 eV of FePc), implying the possible presence of an axial ligand [52,53]. At the same time, the absorption edge of Fe2O3/FeSA@NC shifts to higher energy relative to the Fe foil and Fe3O4 but lower energy relative to Fe2O3, implying positively charged Fe species with valence states close to +3 [54,55]. Furthermore, the Fourier transform (FT) EXAFS spectra of Fe2O3/FeSA@NC show a major peak at ∼1.56 Å (Fig. 3e), agreeing well with the Fe–N(O) bonds. Notably, the Fe–Fe peak at ∼2.23 Å was not observed, reassuring no metallic Fe in Fe2O3/FeSA@NC. However, two small peaks located at ∼2.4 and 3 Å can be detected, which represent the Fe–Fe coordination in the Fe2O3 reference, providing strong evidence for the formation of Fe2O3 in Fe2O3/FeSA@NC [56–58]. The different peak intensities (∼3 Å) are also indicative of the difference in Fe2O3 content in the Fe2O3/FeSA@NC samples. A good fit of the FT-EXAFS spectra was achieved (Fig. 3f and Fig. S12), and Table S5 provides the detailed fitting parameters. The coordination number of Fe single atoms in L-Fe2O3/FeSA@NC and M−Fe2O3/FeSA@NC is calculated to be ∼6, suggesting the possible formation of the Fe-N4 configuration in the plane adsorbed with two oxygen atoms in the axial direction (insert atomic structure model in Fig. 3f), as also reported in previous studies [52–54,59]. In view of the ambient atmosphere when carrying out XAS measurement, the isolated Fe atom is supposed to be coordinated with both N and O atoms [53]. In conclusion, the above combined XAS, XPS and STEM analysis also verify the coexistence of Fe2O3 and atomically dispersed Fe in Fe2O3/FeSA@NC. The ORR performance of the Fe2O3/FeSA@NC catalysts was assessed using a three-electrode system. Catalytic tests were also taken for the Fe-free NC and Pt/C catalyst for comparisons. All tested potentials presented are calibrated to the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE). Cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurements in Ar/O2-saturated alkaline electrolytes were carried out (Fig. S13). Unlike the featureless CV curve in an Ar-saturated solution, one cathodic peak can be clearly seen when measured in an O2-saturated solution, indicating ORR process actually occurs. In the linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) measurements (Fig. 4 a), M−Fe2O3/FeSA@NC shows the highest ORR activity among three Fe2O3/FeSA@NC catalysts in terms of onset potential (E onset) of 1.05 V, half-wave potential (E 1/2) of 0.84 V and a diffusion-limiting current density (J d) of 6.3 mA cm−2, which are also superior to those of Pt/C, NC and most Fe-based catalysts as reported (Table S6). Meanwhile, the kinetic current density (J k) of M−Fe2O3/FeSA@NC is 14.62 mA cm−2 at 0.80 V (Fig. 4b), which is 2-fold higher than that of Pt/C, suggesting the superior ORR kinetics and catalytic activity of M−Fe2O3/FeSA@NC. For the evaluation of catalyst intrinsic activity, double layer capacitance (C dl) (Fig. S14a–d) was adopted to measure the electrochemical active surface area (ECSA) of Fe2O3/FeSA@NC sample. The ECSA for Fe2O3/FeSA@NC catalysts is much larger than that of Fe-free NC (Fig. S14e), indicating that the Fe species in Fe2O3/FeSA@NC dominate the ORR active sites. To rule out possible contribution of ECSA to the ORR activity, the J k values were normalized by the measured ECSA. As presented in Fig. 4(c), M−Fe2O3/FeSA@NC displays the highest intrinsic activity. Additionally, this M−Fe2O3/FeSA@NC sample has a Tafel slope of 75 mV dec–1, smaller than that of Pt/C (78 mV dec–1, Fig. 4d), which further confirms its fast ORR kinetics. The kinetics of catalysts can also be revealed by electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS). Nyquist plots (Fig. S15) show a smaller charge-transfer resistance for the optimized M−Fe2O3/FeSA@NC compared with L-Fe2O3/FeSA@NC, H-Fe2O3/FeSA@NC and NC, indicating a faster electron transfer during the ORR process. In order to reveal the ORR selectivity, LSV curves were taken at different rotating speeds (400–2500 r min−1) (Fig. 4e and Fig. S16). The Koutecky-Levich equation was adopted for calculating the electron transfer number (n). The average n for M−Fe2O3/FeSA@NC was estimated to be ∼4, confirming dominant selectivity toward the 4e– ORR process. The rotating ring-disk electrode (RRDE) was further adopted to assess the selectivity (Fig. 4f). All tested currents are corrected for capacitive currents by LSV measurement in Ar-saturated electrolyte (Fig. S17). M−Fe2O3/FeSA@NC possesses low H2O2 yield (<2%) and high n (3.96–3.98) in the range of 0.2–0.8 V, comparable to the Pt/C and consistent with the n value estimated from the K-L curves. All these observations illustrate that the optimized M−Fe2O3/FeSA@NC with moderate Fe2O3 content catalyzes the ORR through an ideal 4e– pathway. Compared with L-Fe2O3/FeSA@NC and H-Fe2O3/FeSA@NC, the enhanced ORR activity of M−Fe2O3/FeSA@NC is possibly associated with some beneficial factors for ORR, including higher ECSA, higher graphitic N content and richer porous structure. Besides the activity, durability and methanol tolerance are also of great significance for industrial scale applications. The durability of the as-prepared catalysts was examined by the accelerated durability test (ADT) with accelerating cycling between 0.4 and 1.0 V in O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH solution. The LSV curves recorded before and after 1000 cycles (Fig. 4g) reveal that no apparent decay in E 1/2 (ΔE 1/2 = 1 mV) occurs for M−Fe2O3/FeSA@NC. In contrast, when tested under identical conditions, the decrements of E 1/2 for L-Fe2O3/FeSA@NC, H-Fe2O3/FeSA@NC and Pt/C are 6, 23 and 27 mV, respectively (Fig. S18). Meanwhile, the E 1/2 of M−Fe2O3/FeSA@NC also remains unchanged after 2000 cycles (Fig. S19). From the HAADF-STEM results (Fig. S20) after the ADT, the single Fe atoms and Fe2O3 nanoclusters still remain in the carbon matrix without noticeable aggregation, evidencing the structural robustness of M−Fe2O3/FeSA@NC during the ORR process. Furthermore, the methanol crossover effect of M−Fe2O3/FeSA@NC was measured by chronoamperometric tests. As seen from Fig. 4(h), a negligible change of the current was observed for M−Fe2O3/FeSA@NC after adding methanol into the alkaline solution, whereas the benchmark Pt/C catalyst displays a dramatic current drop due to methanol poisoning, indicating this M−Fe2O3/FeSA@NC sample could tolerate methanol crossover to a much larger extend. As a whole, all of the above electrochemical results (including high half-wave potential and kinetic current density, 4e– pathway, superior durability and methanol tolerance) demonstrate that the as-prepared M−Fe2O3/FeSA@NC catalyst comprising Fe single atoms coupled with a moderate amount of Fe2O3 nanoclusters anchored on N-doped porous carbons is a highly promising PGM-free ORR electrocatalyst under alkaline conditions. To better clarify the critical role of Fe2O3 groups in enhancing the catalytic activity, we additionally prepared a pure single-atom Fe catalyst (denoted as FeSA@NC (by acid wash)) by removing the Fe2O3 clusters in M−Fe2O3/FeSA@NC via acid wash treatment [60,61]. The removal of Fe2O3 clusters and the sole existence of single-atom Fe in the FeSA@NC (by acid wash) were confirmed by HAADF-STEM (Fig. S21) and XAS results (Fig. S22). The FeSA@NC (by acid wash) has a more negative E 1/2, larger H2O2 yield and smaller n values as to M−Fe2O3/FeSA@NC (Fig. 4i and Fig. S23), validating the effectiveness of the Fe2O3 group toward improving the ORR activity. Besides, the BET surface area and pore volume of FeSA@NC (by acid wash) were determined by N2 adsorption–desorption measurements and the results are displayed in Table S7. Similar surface area between FeSA@NC and M−Fe2O3/FeSA@NC suggests that the contribution of activity enhancement is resulted from the intrinsic electronic interations rather than the amount of active sites, which will be studied by the density functional theory (DFT) calculations as follows. To better understand the unique contribution of Fe2O3 nanoclusters for the excellent activity in Fe2O3/FeSA@NC, DFT calculations were carried out. The associative mechanism with the 4e– pathway and HOO*, O*, and HO* (* denotes the adsorption site) intermediates were chosen here [62,63]. Two atomic models, namely, FeSA@NC and Fe2O3/FeSA@NC, were constructed to represent the interactions between the Fe-N4 moiety and Fe2O3 cluster on the carbon skeleton. The solvation effect was considered by adding one water layer on both sides of the systems. O-containing intermediates (HOO*, O*, and HO*) with optimized configurations on FeSA@NC and Fe2O3/FeSA@NC are displayed on the right side in Fig. 5 (a and b). As seen from Fig. 5(a and b), the free energy diagrams on FeSA@NC and Fe2O3/FeSA@NC show both downhill energy pathways at U = 0 V, confirming a spontaneous exothermal process. When the bias potential U = 1.23 V (equilibrium potential) is applied, the highest uphill free energy is indicated as the rate-determining step (RDS). For FeSA@NC, the RDS is the H2O formation via the HO* intermediate, which is consistent with previous DFT calculations [17,64]. The corresponding theoretical overpotential for FeSA@NC is as large as 0.99 V, suggesting that the interaction between HO* and the Fe-N4 moiety is too strong, which limits the overall ORR performance. For Fe2O3/FeSA@NC, the RDS is still the last step for the formation of water. However, the theoretical overpotential is significantly reduced to 0.34 V. This matches the superior ORR performance of the Fe2O3/FeSA@NC system observed in the experiments. Fe2O3 can effectively facilitate the formation of water on the Fe-N4 sites, even though Fe2O3 itself is not active for ORR (Figs. S24 and S25). Previous studies have demonstrated that the binding strength between active site and O-containing intermediates can be evaluated by the d-band center [4,65,66]. To this end, the electronic configurations of active Fe atoms in FeSA@NC and Fe2O3/FeSA@NC were also analyzed. It is worth noting that all the orbitals are occupied by electrons in the spin-up state based on crystal field theory. As a result, it is more meaningful to calculate the d-center of spin-down states to examine the reactivity of the active sites. The projected density of states (DOS) of the d-band of the active Fe atoms in FeSA@NC and Fe2O3/FeSA@NC is presented in Fig. 5(c). The d-band center of Fe spin-down states (1.17 eV) in Fe2O3/FeSA@NC shifts to a lower energy level when compared with Fe in FeSA@NC (1.29 eV). According to the d-band center theory [4,65,66], a decrease in the d-band center weakens the adsorption of HO* on the Fe active center, which can facilitate the RDS step for the formation of water. Charge density difference (CDD) and Bader charge analyses were employed to elucidate the origin of this Fe d-band shift. As displayed in the CDD diagram (Fig. 5d), regions around active Fe atom have shown a strong sign of electron depletion (blue), indicating electron transfer from the active Fe site within the central Fe-N4 moieties to the adjacent Fe2O3 cluster. Additionally, the Bader charge of the active Fe atom in Fe2O3/FeSA@NC (1.7 |e|) is larger than that in FeSA@NC (1.1 |e|). These CDD and charge analysis results demonstrate that the introduction of Fe2O3 can lead active Fe atoms to carry more positive charges, which is consistent with previous XANES data (Fig. 3d and Fig. S22a). Moreover, the magnetic moment of atomic Fe sites in FeSA@NC calculated from the DFT calculations is approximately 2 μB, in agreement with the electronic configuration of Fe(II) in the traditional square-planar field (Fig. 5e) [17,53]. As a comparison, the atomic Fe sites in Fe2O3/FeSA@NC have a magnetic moment of ∼5 μB, matching well with the electronic configuration of Fe(III) in a tetrahedral field (Fig. 5f). The change in the magnetic moments is confirmed by the DOS images (Fig. 5c), which show almost no spin-down electrons in the bonding area in Fe2O3/FeSA@NC. More unoccupied spin-down states are found close to the Fermi level in the tetrahedral field for Fe2O3/FeSA@NC, thereby resulting in a decrease in the Fe d-band center of the spin-down states. The DFT results suggest that the optimized adsorption Gibbs free energy change of oxygen-containing intermediates and improved ORR performance are attributed to the Fe2O3 cluster, which can modify the electronic configurations of atomically dispersed Fe in Fe-N4 via charge redistribution and crystal field alteration. To assess the potential application of the M−Fe2O3/FeSA@NC catalyst for energy storage and conversion devices, an aqueous primary zinc-air battery was constructed by mixing M−Fe2O3/FeSA@NC and RuO2 (denoted below as M−Fe2O3/FeSA@NC-based catalyst) as the cathode catalyst in the 6.0 M KOH solution consisting of 0.2 M (Zn(OAc)2). The configuration of the battery is schematically illustrated in Fig. 6 (a). As a comparison, commercial PGM catalysts (Pt/C + RuO2, denoted below as Pt/C-based catalyst) with the same catalyst loading were also employed as the air cathode for the ZAB. As presented in Fig. 6(b and c), the ZAB with the M−Fe2O3/FeSA@NC-based catalyst exhibits an open circuit voltage of 1.45 V and a high peak power density of 155 mW cm−2 at 300 mA cm−2, which are slightly higher than those of the ZAB with the Pt/C-based catalyst (1.41 V, 150 mW cm−2@290 mA cm−2). The ZAB with the M−Fe2O3/FeSA@NC-based catalyst shows a specific capacity (on the basis of Zn anode mass loss) of 762 mA h gZn −1 at 20 mA cm−2 (Fig. 6c). The rechargeable ZAB stability was further evaluated by adopting long-term galvanostatic cycling at 5 mA cm−2 (1 h/cycle). Notably, a slightly larger voltage gap (between the charging voltage and discharging voltage) was observed for the ZAB with the M−Fe2O3/FeSA@NC-based catalyst over a period of 200 h (0.88 V at 25 cycles and 0.92 V at 200 cycles), in contrast to Pt/C which has a significant increase in the voltage gap (Fig. 6d), highlighting the superior stability of M−Fe2O3/FeSA@NC. These results demonstrate the great promise of M−Fe2O3/FeSA@NC toward industrial application of rechargeable ZABs. 4 Conclusions In summary, a facile cage-encapsulated-precursor pyrolysis strategy was proposed to develop a series of ORR electrocatalysts comprising single-atom Fe sites integrated with ultra-small Fe2O3 nanoclusters/nanoparticles anchored on N-doped porous carbons (denoted as Fe2O3/FeSA@NC). When a moderate Fe2O3 content is achieved in Fe2O3/FeSA@NC, the optimized M−Fe2O3/FeSA@NC catalyst exhibits excellent ORR activity (E onset = 1.05 V, E 1/2 = 0.84 V, J k = 14.62 mA cm−2 at 0.80 V), robust stability and strong methanol tolerance, outperforming Pt/C (E onset = 0.97 V, E 1/2 = 0.82 V, J k = 6.89 mA cm−2 at 0.80 V) and most of the reported Fe containing catalysts. Compared with Fe2O3/FeSA@NC catalysts with high and low Fe2O3 contents (E onset = 0.91 V, E 1/2 = 0.78 V, J k = 2.79 mA cm−2 at 0.80 V for H-Fe2O3/FeSA@NC and E onset = 1.0 V, E 1/2 = 0.76 V, J k = 2.77 mA cm−2 at 0.80 V for L-Fe2O3/FeSA@NC), superior ORR activity mainly originates from higher ECSA, richer porous structure and higher graphitic N content. Remarkably, the ZAB driven by the mixture of M−Fe2O3/FeSA@NC and RuO2 shows excellent performance including a peak power density of 155 mW cm−2, a specific capacity of 762 mA h gZn −1 and robust stability over a period of 200 h, exceeding the Pt/C-based ZAB. Theoretical calculations reveal that the introduction of Fe2O3 can induce electron redistribution and coordination environment changes in the active Fe sites of FeSA@NC, which can optimize the HO* adsorption Gibbs free energy and reduce the theoretical overpotential of the ORR. It is in our believe that this work could shed light on the rational modulation of the electronic configurations of the active single-atom sites via introduction of moderate metal oxide phases. coredata.dc:description: Metal-air batteries face a great challenge in developing efficient and durable low-cost oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) electrocatalysts. Single-atom iron catalysts embedded into nitrogen doped carbon (Fe-N-C) have emerged as attractive materials for potential replacement of Pt in ORR, but their catalytic performance was limited by the symmetrical electronic structure distribution around the single-atom Fe site. Here, we report our findings in significantly enhancing the ORR performance of Fe-N-C by moderate Fe2O3 integration via the strong electronic interaction. Remarkably, the optimized catalyst (M−Fe2O3/FeSA@NC) exhibits excellent activity, durability and good tolerance to methanol, outperforming the benchmark Pt/C catalyst. When M−Fe2O3/FeSA@NC catalyst was used in a practical zinc-air battery assembly, peak power density of 155 mW cm−2 and specific capacity of 762 mA h gZn −1 were achieved and the battery assembly has shown superior cycling stability over a period of 200 h. More importantly, theoretical studies suggest that the introduction of Fe2O3 can evoke the crystal field alteration and electron redistribution on single Fe atoms, which can break the symmetric charge distribution of Fe-N4 and thereby optimize the corresponding adsorption energy of intermediates to promote the O2 reduction. This study provides a new pathway to promote the catalytic performance of single-atom catalysts.
